 HYPOXEMIA
 ATRIAL FIBRILLATION (AFIB)
   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called
   out from MICU after prolonged hospital course complicated by LLL
   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   .
   # Fever: New fever this morning as well as leukocytosis and bandemia.
   She has several possible sources including recurrent pna, UTI, pleural
   fluid. The persistant hypoxia depsite fluid removal as well as thick
   secretions is concerning for recurrent PNA, although this mornings CXR
   (obtained at time of spike) does not look much worse. The G tube site
   looks good and not infected.
   - f/u blood cx, urine cx, sputum cx,pleural fluid cx
   - send stool cx when able
   - will start Vanc/ Zosyn for now for broad coverage of HA
   - will need to swap out lines
   ..
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. Currently, I suspect a component of pulm edema in setting of
   getting extra IVF and starting TF as well as afib with RVR and possibly
   flash pulm edema. CXR at time of transfer without evidence of worsening
   PTX. No LE swelling, she has been on DVT ppx, but PE also remains on
   differential, although lower suspicion at this time. EKG without signs
   of right heart strain
   - goal diuresis 1 L neg today with IV lasix
   - check PM lytes and replete as needed
   - f/u infectious w/u
   .
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation - she was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor
   - Continue ASA
   - monitor on tele
   - continue metoprolol 12.5 TID PO
   - complete IV amiodarone load today and switch to PO
   .
   # Altered mental status: per team, yesterday, she was still able to
   communicate with team, at times disoriented. Currently, she is much
   more somnolent per history. I suspect this may be related to morphine.
   By the evening, before temp spike, mental status had improved.
   - hold sedating meds
   .
   # HAP/Aspiraton PNA #1 - Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly
   covered with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has
   completed course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions
   and a trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring
   bipap at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed
   evidence of numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**]
   did not reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR yesterday with increased effusion so
   pigtail unclamped and has drained 1 L.
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated
   - Xopenex/Ipratropium nebs
   - f/u IP recs
   .
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - continue pigtail to water seal
   - F/U IP recommendatiosn regarding pigtail, when to remove
   .
   # [**Name (NI) 5860**] pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started
   .
   # Borderline hypotension- Her blood pressures have been running in the
   80's-90's systolic during her admission, asymptomatic. Here, blood
   pressure has been 100s recently, stable
   - continue metoprolol PO for rate control
   - no further interventions if asymptomatic
   .
   #. Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   .
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili
   also not elevated. Iron studies not c/w iron deficiency
   - continue to monitor
   .
   Access: PICC
   FEN: NPO, started TFs
   PPX: heparin sq, bowel reg prn, ppi
   Code status: This was readdressed with the patient, PCP, [**Name10 (NameIs) **] guardian,
   and pt clearly expressed desire to remain full code.
   .
   Communication: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2084**] Guardian [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5691**] or [**Telephone/Fax (1) 5692**]
   Dispo: Pending resolution of pleural effusion, removal of [**Hospital 1650**] rehab
   placement
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- Patient admitted with hypoxia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and fever.
- Patient has a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and previous hospital course complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, pleural effusion, and trapped lung.
- Patient's current condition includes persistent hypoxia despite fluid removal, thick secretions, leukocytosis, and bandemia.
- Possible sources of infection include recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection, and pleural fluid.
- Patient's mental status has fluctuated, with periods of disorientation and somnolence.
- Patient has been on various medications including amiodarone, metoprolol, heparin, furosemide, and lasix.
- Patient underwent thoracentesis and placement of a pigtail catheter for pleural effusion, which improved respiratory status.
- Patient's pleural effusion reaccumulated, and the pigtail catheter was unclamped and drained over 1 liter.
- Patient failed a video swallow test and is currently NPO with a feeding tube in place.
- Patient's blood pressures have been running in the 80's-90's systolic during admission but have recently stabilized in the 100s.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Pneumonia: The patient's persistent hypoxia, thick secretions, and leukocytosis raise concerns for recurrent pneumonia.
2.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 86-year-old female with a medical history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and previous hospitalization for left lower lobe pneumonia. She has been admitted to the ICU for her prolonged hospital course complicated by pneumonia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and acute kidney injury.

The patient's current condition includes hypoxia, fever, and altered mental status. She has been on mechanical ventilation and has required increasing levels of oxygen support due to respiratory distress. The patient also has a history of recurrent pneumonia, pleural effusion, and trapped lung, for which she underwent thoracentesis and placement of a pigtail catheter.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 101.7°F (38.7°C), heart rate of 116 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 105/43 mmHg to 160/119 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on aerosol-cool delivery device. The patient's ABG results indicate a pH of 7.43, PaCO2 of 53 mmHg, and PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 97.

   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR yesterday with increased effusion so

Summary:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and previous hospitalization for left lower lobe pneumonia. She was admitted to the ICU with hypoxia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and fever. The patient has been experiencing prolonged hospitalization complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, trap lung, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent Pneumonia: The patient's persistent hypoxia despite fluid removal and thick secretions is concerning for recurrent pneumonia. She has several possible sources including recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection (UTI), and pleural fluid.
2. Pulmonary Edema: The patient has been hypoxic for numerous reasons during her extended hospital stay. Currently, I suspect a component of pulmonary edema in the setting of getting extra intravenous fluids and starting total parenteral nutrition (TF), as well as atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and possibly flash pulmonary edema. Chest X-ray at the time of transfer does not show evidence of worsening pulmonary edema.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) and Pulmonary Embolism (PE): Although the patient has been on DVT prophylaxis, PE remains on the differential, although lower suspicion at this time. Electrocardiogram (EKG) without signs of right heart strain.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR), and a history of lung problems. She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and developed a large left effusion with a trapped lung after placement of a Pleurex catheter. She also had an open J-tube placed. The patient had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation that improved with the Pleurex catheter. 

Upon her return to the ICU, she experienced IV fluid boluses the previous night for low urine output and received Lopressor 2.5 mg IV twice with improvement of heart rate to the 100s. She also received 20 IV Lasix with an 800 cc urine output. Additionally, she received 2 mg IV morphine.

The patient's current vital signs show a temperature of 101.7°F (Tmax), heart rate in the 110s (HR), blood pressure ranging from 97/71 to 100/60 mmHg (BP), respiratory rate in the 30s (RR), and oxygen saturation at 98% on HiFlow mask. Her heart rhythm is still in atrial fibrillation (AF). The patient appears uncomfortable and cannot relate any further history.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia, subsequent large left effusion, and a trapped lung. The patient underwent pleural catheter placement, which improved her condition. She has been in the ICU for a prolonged stay due to AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation. 

On the floor, she received an open gastrostomy tube placement and was started on tube feeding. Her chest tube remained in place as there continued to be daily drainage of 300-400 cc. The team was screening her for rehab, but today she experienced an episode of AF RVR with a heart rate in the 140s and worsening oxygen requirement. She required a higher flow oxygen mask to maintain mid to high 90s saturation levels. 

She received IV fluid boluses the previous night for low urine output and responded to 2.5 mg IV Lopressor with improvement of heart rate to the 100s. She also received 20 IV Lasix with an 800 cc urine output. Additionally, she received 2 mg IV morphine.

Upon arrival to the ICU, the patient was not talking and appeared uncomfortable. She could not provide any further history. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. AF RVR: The patient continues to have episodes of AF RVR,

The patient has undergone several interventions and treatments, including the placement of a pigtail catheter for pleural effusion drainage, initiation of diuretics, and administration of antibiotics. The patient's vital signs show persistent tachycardia and hypoxia despite these interventions.

2. Pleural effusion: The patient has a left-sided transudative pleural effusion and trapped lung. The effusion has reaccumulated, and the pigtail catheter needs to be unclamped to monitor for any worsening.

3. Aspiration pneumonia: Given the patient's altered mental status and inability to protect their airway, there is a risk of aspiration leading to aspiration pneumonia. The patient's feeding tube has been started to minimize this risk.

4. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response requires careful management with rate control medications. The patient's low blood

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient has multiple medical complications and conditions. Some potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has a new fever this morning along with leukocytosis and bandemia. Possible sources of infection include recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection, pleural fluid, and others. Broad-spectrum antibiotics have been started for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) coverage.

2. Hypoxemia: The patient has been hypoxic for various reasons during the extended hospital stay. Possible causes include pulmonary edema, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), flash pulmonary edema, and possibly a patent foramen ovale (PFO) or atrial septal defect (ASD). Heparin and Lasix infusions have been started empirically for potential pulmonary embolism (PE) and fluid overload, respectively.

Low-dose metoprolol is being continued for rate control, and amiodarone has been started. Additional beta-blocker doses have been required due to persistent tachycardia.

   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called

   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   # Fever: New fever this morning as well as leukocytosis and bandemia.
   She has several possible sources including recurrent pna, UTI, pleural
   fluid. The persistant hypoxia depsite fluid removal as well as thick
   secretions is concerning for recurrent PNA, although this mornings CXR
   (obtained at time of spike) does not look much worse. The G tube site
   looks good and not infected.

   - consider exchanging PICC if no improvement
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. Currently, I suspect a component of pulm edema in setting of
   getting extra IVF and starting TF as well as afib with RVR and possibly
   flash pulm edema. CXR at time of transfer without evidence of worsening
   PTX. No LE swelling, she has been on DVT ppx, but PE also remains on
   differential, although lower suspicion at this time. EKG without signs
   of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very high Pao2 suggestive of
   possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well, but Bubble study does
   show shunt, likely ASD/PFO. Started on heparin gtt and lasix gtt last
   night given TTE findings.
   - Lasix gtt to diurese carefully
   - Heparin gtt empirically for PEs
   - following [**Hospital1 **] lytes, replete PRN
   - f/u infectious w/u
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation - she was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of
   the night, requiring additional BB doses. Not limited by hypotension.
   - titrate back up on Lopressor carefully
   - cont Amiodarone, ASA
   - monitor on tele
   - wil not restart digoxin
   # Altered mental status: per team, yesterday, she was still able to
   communicate with team, at times disoriented. Currently, she is much
   more somnolent per history. I suspect this may be related to morphine.
   By the evening, before temp spike, mental status had improved.
   - hold sedating meds
   # HAP/Aspiraton PNA #1 - Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly
   covered with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has
   completed course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions
   and a trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring
   bipap at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed
   evidence of numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**]
   did not reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR with increased effusion so pigtail
   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without
   worsening of effusion on CXRs since. Weaning O2 slowly.
   - cont pigtail clamped, monitor
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated

   - f/u IP recs
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - continue pigtail to water seal
   - F/U IP recommendatiosn regarding pigtail, when to remove
   # [**Name (NI) 5860**] pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started

   80's-90's systolic during her admission, asymptomatic. Here, blood
   pressure has been 100s recently, but now dipped to SBP 80
s after lasix
   and metoprolol. However, low BP, fever and bandemia could be impending
   sepsis. Given TTE findings, started on Lasix gtt yesterday to carefully
   diurese.
   - cont Lasix gtt for careful diuresis, avoid boluses
   - no further interventions if asymptomatic , keep >50 if mentating at
   baseline
   #. Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili

   - continue to monitor

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. She was admitted to the ICU with pneumonia and developed a left lower lobe pneumonia, resulting in pleural effusion and trapped lung. The patient required high-flow mask oxygen and bipap at night. A chest CT revealed numerous distal mucous plugs, but bronchoscopy did not show large mucous plugs. Thoracentesis was performed, and the patient had immediate improvement in respiratory status after drainage of transudative fluid. A pigtail catheter was placed, and the patient continues to drain fluid without worsening of effusion. The patient's current condition includes fever of unknown origin, hypoxemia, atrial fibrillation, altered mental status, HAP/Aspiration PNA, pleural effusion, and borderline hypotension. The patient is NPO with tube feeding started, and a G tube is in place. She is on various medications including amiodarone, metoprolol, heparin, lasix, and others. The patient's code status is full code, and her disposition is pending resolution of pleural effusion and removal of PICC line.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Recurrent pneumonia due to thick secretions and mucous plugs in the lungs.
2. Pulmonary edema caused by fluid overload and heart failure.
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT

Summary:
Summary of the progress note:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR), and other medical conditions. She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and developed a large left effusion, leading to a trapped lung. A Pleurex catheter was placed, continuously producing 400cc/day. An open Jejunostomy (J) tube was also placed. She had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation that improved with the Pleurex catheter. On the floor, she did well, and her chest tube remained in place due to ongoing drainage. The team was screening her for rehab. However, today, she experienced AF RVR with a heart rate in the 140s, worsening oxygen requirement, and an increase in chest tube drainage. She received IV fluids, Lopressor, Lasix, and morphine. Upon arrival in the ICU, she was not talking and appeared uncomfortable. She could not provide further history.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Respiratory complications: Due to her history of pneumonia, trapped lung, and ongoing chest tube drainage, there is a risk of further respiratory infections or complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
2. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's poorly controlled AF RVR and previous hypotension indicate

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia, subsequent large left effusion, and a trapped lung. A pigtail catheter was placed, and she underwent an open jejunostomy tube placement. The patient had a prolonged ICU stay for atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypotension, and desaturation that improved with the pleural catheter. 

Upon returning to the floor, she received intravenous fluids, went into atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and developed worsening oxygen requirements. She was given IV boluses for low urine output, received lopressor to control her heart rate, and received IV lasix. She also received 2 mg IV morphine. 

Upon arrival in the ICU, she was not talking and appeared uncomfortable. She had an oxygen requirement of 70% on high flow mask and was transitioned to PO amiodarone. Her condition worsened, with hypoxemia requiring 35% face mask oxygen. A transesophageal echocardiogram with bubble study showed an atrial septal defect (ASD) and patent foramen ovale (PFO), along with a dilated right ventricle suggestive of a pulmonary embolism (PE). Heparin was started empirically. 

The patient's chest tube was

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia and developed a large left pleural effusion. A pleural catheter was placed, and she also had an open Jejunostomy tube (J-tube) placed. 

The patient had a prolonged ICU stay due to AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the placement of the pleural catheter. She was started on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) and amiodarone for her AF RVR. On the floor, she was doing well, but today she experienced another episode of AF RVR with a heart rate in the 140s and worsening oxygen requirements. She required a high-flow nasal cannula to maintain her oxygen saturation in the mid-to-high 90s.

She received IV fluids the previous night for low urine output and was given lopressor 2.5 mg IV twice, which helped control her heart rate. She also received 20 mg IV lasix with an 800 cc urine output. Additionally, she received 2 mg IV morphine. Upon arrival in the ICU, she was not talking and appeared uncomfortable, unable to provide further history.

The patient has several potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Hypoxemic Respiratory

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia, developed a large left effusion, and had a pigtail catheter placed. She also has a history of prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation. The patient's current presentation includes worsening oxygen requirement, development of fever, slight bandemia, and altered mental status. She continues to have episodes of AF RVR and has been receiving IV fluids.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia may be related to her AF RVR and flash edema. If rate control does not improve her condition, pulmonary embolism (PE) should be considered in the differential diagnosis. Repeating ABG and VBG, getting a transthoracic echo (TTE) with bubble study, and starting IV heparin may be necessary.
2. Fever and Slight Bandemia: The patient has a fever and slight bandemia, indicating a possible infection. Pan culture was done, and empiric Vanc/Zosyn coverage was started. Diuresis should be avoided.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status is altered, possibly due to narcotics. Checking ABG to ensure she is not retaining CO2, holding sedating medications,

She has been admitted to the ICU due to recurrent pneumonia, atrial fibrillation, and hypoxemia. She has been on broad-spectrum antibiotics for hospital-acquired pneumonia, but continues to have fevers, leukocytosis, and bandemia. She also has a left-sided pleural effusion and trapped lung, which has been managed with chest tube placement and drainage.

Her physical examination reveals minimal responsiveness, opening eyes to name but not following commands, irregularly irregular heart rhythm, decreased breath sounds throughout, and no wheezes. She has a well-healed midline surgical scar with a ventral hernia and PEG insertion clean.

   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called
   out from MICU after prolonged hospital course complicated by LLL
   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   # Fever: New fever this morning as well as leukocytosis and bandemia.
   She has several possible sources including recurrent pna, UTI, pleural
   fluid. The persistant hypoxia depsite fluid removal as well as thick
   secretions is concerning for recurrent PNA, although this mornings CXR
   (obtained at time of spike) does not look much worse. The G tube site
   looks good and not infected.
   - f/u blood cx, urine cx, sputum cx, pleural fluid cx, stool cx
   - will start Vanc/ Zosyn for now for broad coverage of HAP
   - consider exchanging PICC if no improvement
   - re-check C.diff to r/o x3
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. Currently, I suspect a component of pulm edema in setting of
   getting extra IVF and starting TF as well as afib with RVR and possibly
   flash pulm edema. CXR at time of transfer without evidence of worsening
   PTX. No LE swelling, she has been on DVT ppx, but PE also remains on
   differential, although lower suspicion at this time. EKG without signs
   of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very high Pao2 suggestive of
   possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well, but Bubble study does
   show shunt, likely ASD/PFO. Started on heparin gtt and lasix gtt last
   night given TTE findings.
   - Lasix gtt to diurese carefully
   - continue lovenox for empriric PE treatment.
   - following [**Hospital1 **] lytes, replete PRN
   - f/u infectious w/u
   - un-clamp chest tube to monitor reaccumulation of pleural effusion
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation - she was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of
   the night, requiring additional BB doses. Not limited by hypotension.
   - titrate Lopressor carefully
   - cont Amiodarone, ASA
   - monitor on tele
   - wil not restart digoxin
   # Altered mental status: per team, yesterday, she was still able to
   communicate with team, at times disoriented. Currently, she is much
   more somnolent per history. I suspect this may be related to morphine.
   By the evening, before temp spike, mental status had improved.
   - hold sedating meds
   # HAP/Aspiraton PNA #1 - Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly
   covered with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has
   completed course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions
   and a trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring
   bipap at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed
   evidence of numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**]
   did not reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR with increased effusion so pigtail
   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without
   worsening of effusion on CXRs since. Weaning O2 slowly.
   - if chest tube drainage less than 100 cc/day, can consider pulling the
   tube
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated
   - Xopenex/Ipratropium nebs
   - f/u IP recs
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - unclamp pigtail
   - F/U IP recommendatiosn regarding pigtail, when to remove
   # ASD/PFO
   - continue to monitor
   # [**Name (NI) 5860**] pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started
   # Borderline hypotension- Her blood pressures have been running in the
   80's-90's systolic during her admission, asymptomatic. Here, blood
   pressure has been 100s recently, but now dipped to SBP 80
s after lasix
   and metoprolol. However, low BP, fever and bandemia could be impending
   sepsis. Given TTE findings, started on Lasix gtt yesterday to carefully
   diurese.
   - cont Lasix gtt for careful diuresis, avoid boluses
   - no further interventions if asymptomatic , keep >50 if mentating at
   baseline
   #. Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili
   also not elevated. Iron studies not c/w iron deficiency
   - continue to monitor
   Access: PICC
   FEN: NPO, started TFs
   PPX: heparin sq, bowel reg prn, stop PPI

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and previous pneumonia. She was admitted to the ICU due to left lower lobe (LLL) pneumonia, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and respiratory failure requiring bipap and high flow mask oxygen.

She initially received broad-spectrum antibiotics for her pneumonia, which was later narrowed to cefepime. However, she developed large pleural effusions and a trapped lung on the left side. Her respiratory status deteriorated, necessitating the use of noninvasive ventilation.

A chest CT revealed numerous distal mucous plugs, and bronchoscopy did not show large mucous plugs. She underwent thoracentesis and drainage of transudative fluid, but the effusion quickly reaccumulated. An IP placed pigtail catheter was inserted, resulting in immediate drainage of a large clear transudative fluid and improvement in her respiratory status. The pigtail catheter was initially clamped, but later unclamped due to the increased effusion.

The patient also has a history of aspiration pneumonia (HAP/Aspiration PNA #1), for which she completed a course of cefepime. She is currently on Vanc/Zosyn for broad coverage of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP).

   daily. The team was screening her for rehab. However, today, she went
   into afib with RVR with HR in 140's, developed a worsening oxygen
   requirement (from 2-3L NC to 70% HiFlow mask) to keep sats in mid to

   for low UOP. On the floor, she received lopressor 2.5 mg IV X 2 with
   improvement of HR to 100's. She recived 20 IV lasix with 800 cc UOP.
   She also received 2 mg IV morphine.
   Upon arrival to the ICU, she was not talking and appears uncomfortable.
   She cannot relate any further history.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR), and other medical conditions. She was initially admitted for left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) with a large left effusion, which was treated with a pleurex catheter and an open J-tube placement. She had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, but improved with the pleurex catheter.

On the floor, the patient underwent surgery for open G-tube placement and was started on tube feeding (TF) on [**5-18**]. Her chest tube remained in place due to ongoing drainage of 300-400 cc clear drainage daily. The team was considering her for rehab, but today she experienced a recurrence of AF RVR with a heart rate in the 140s, worsening oxygen requirements, and low urine output.

Interventions:
- IV fluids (IVF) boluses for low urine output
- Lopressor 2.5 mg IV twice to control heart rate
- 20 IV Lasix with 800 cc urine output
- 2 mg IV morphine

Assessment and Plan:
The patient's current assessment includes fever of unknown origin (FUO), high risk for fall, hypoxemia, and atrial fibrillation (AF).

Potential Medical Complications:
Based on the information provided, potential medical complications that can arise include:
1. Respiratory complications: The patient has a history of pneumonia and ongoing chest tube drainage, which increases the risk of respiratory infections and further respiratory compromise.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response may lead to hemodynamic instability, poor tissue perfusion, and potential cardiac arrhythmias.
3. Infectious complications: The presence of fever of unknown origin suggests the possibility of an ongoing infection, which may require further investigation and treatment.
4. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient has had an open J-tube placement, indicating a risk of gastrointestinal infections or complications related to enteral feeding.
5. Neurological complications: The patient's inability to communicate or provide further history raises concerns about potential neurological deterioration or cognitive impairment.

It is important to closely monitor the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, cardiac rhythm, fluid balance, and laboratory values to promptly identify and manage any potential complications that may arise.

   86 year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly
   controlled AF c RVR initially admitted with LLL PNA subsequent large
   left effusion and ? trapped lung s/p pigtail catheter that is
   continuously producing (400cc/day past 24 hrs).  She is s/p open J

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia and developed a large left pleural effusion. A pigtail catheter was placed, and she also had an open J-tube placed. The patient had a prolonged ICU stay due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the pleural catheter. She returned to the ICU today after receiving IV fluids on the floor, experiencing atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and desaturation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response (AFib with RVR): The patient has a history of AFib with RVR, which can lead to an irregular heartbeat and a decrease in cardiac output. This may result in symptoms such as dizziness, fainting, and fatigue. Treatment includes medications like amiodarone and cardizem, along with anticoagulation therapy.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has multifactorial hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and right ventricular dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism (PE). This can cause inadequate oxygenation of the blood and may require mechanical ventilation support.
3.

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was admitted initially with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and subsequently developed a large left pleural effusion, possibly due to a trapped lung. She underwent placement of a pigtail catheter, which continuously drained 400cc of fluid per day. An open J-tube was also placed. The patient had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the pleural catheter. On the floor, she received IV fluids and experienced an episode of AF RVR, leading to worsening oxygen requirements. She was transitioned to PO amiodarone and received IV lasix and morphine. Upon arrival to the ICU, she was not talking and appeared uncomfortable.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has multifactorial hypoxic respiratory failure, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and right ventricular (RV) dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism (PE).
2. Fever and Slight Bandemia: The patient has a fever and slight bandemia, indicating a possible infection. She has been pan-cultured and started on vancomycin and Zosyn for coverage. Repeat sputum cultures

   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called

   # Fever: Recent fever as well as leukocytosis and bandemia. She has
   several possible sources including recurrent pna, UTI, pleural fluid.
   The persistant hypoxia depsite fluid removal as well as thick
   secretions is concerning for recurrent PNA, although this mornings CXR
   (obtained at time of spike) does not look much worse. The G tube site
   looks good and not infected. Now 48 hrs afebrile and with resolving
   leukocytosis.
   - f/u blood cx, urine cx, sputum cx, pleural fluid cx, stool cx

   - consider exchanging PICC if no improvement

   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. PE also remains on differential, and will treat emprically for
   PE. EKG without signs of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very
   high Pao2 suggestive of possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well,
   but Bubble study does show shunt, likely ASD/PFO. Started on heparin
   gtt and lasix gtt last night given TTE findings.

   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of

   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which

   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and a prolonged hospital course complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, trap lung, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She is currently in the ICU and has several ongoing medical complications.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fever, Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has had recent fevers along with leukocytosis and bandemia. Possible sources include recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection (UTI), pleural fluid, among others. Further investigations are needed to identify the cause of the fever.

2. Hypoxemia: Despite fluid removal and thick secretions, the patient remains hypoxic. This may indicate recurrent pneumonia or a possible pulmonary embolism (PE). Empirical treatment for PE is being administered, and a bubble study has shown a shunt, likely atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent foramen ovale (PFO). Heparin gtt and Lasix gtt have been started.

3. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient has been in and out of AFib on the floor. She is currently on low-dose metoprolol for rate control, but her heart rate remains elevated. Diltiazem has been added, and the dosing will be titrated carefully. Amiodarone will continue to be administered

Summary:
Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for this patient:

1. Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO): The patient has had recent fevers along with leukocytosis and bandemia. Possible sources of infection include recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection (UTI), pleural fluid, or catheter-related bloodstream infection.

2. Hypoxemia: The patient has been hypoxic for numerous reasons, including pulmonary edema, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), and possibly flash pulmonary edema. A bubble study showed a shunt, likely an atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent foramen ovale (PFO).

3. Paroxysmal Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): The patient has a history of AFib, which can increase the risk of stroke. The patient is currently on amiodarone and aspirin for rate control and stroke prevention.

4. Trapped Lung and Pleural Effusion: The patient has a left-sided transudative pleural effusion and trapped lung. The pigtail catheter placed in the pleural space has been draining fluid, but it needs to be monitored closely.

5. Borderline Hypotension: The patient's blood pressures have been running low, especially after receiving lasix and metoprolol. This could be due to sepsis or the diuretic effect of lasix.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. She was admitted to the ICU due to a prolonged hospital course complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, trap lung, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's current condition includes fever of unknown origin, high risk for falls, hypoxemia, atrial fibrillation, altered mental status, hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), aspiration pneumonia, pleural effusion, ASD/PFO, borderline hypotension, anemia, and schizophrenia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Fever of unknown origin: The patient has been experiencing fevers, which could indicate an underlying infection or inflammation. Further investigation is needed to determine the cause.

2. High risk for falls: Due to the patient's altered mental status and physical limitations, she is at a high risk for falls. Measures should be taken to prevent falls and minimize the risk of injury.

3. Hypoxemia: The patient continues to have difficulty maintaining adequate oxygen levels in her blood. This could be due to recurrent pneumonia, pulmonary edema, or an underlying cardiac condition. Continuous monitoring and treatment adjustments are necessary to improve oxygenation.

4. Atrial fibrillation: The patient has a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and it has been present during her hospital stay. Rate control is essential to prevent symptoms such as palpitations, short

TEXT:
I saw and examined the patient, and was physically present with the ICU
   Resident for key portions of the services provided.  I agree with his /
   her note, including assessment and plan as detailed in my note below.
   Chief Complaint:  afib with RVR, hypoxia
   HPI:
   86 year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly
   controlled AF c RVR initially admitted with LLL PNA subsequent large
   left effusion and ? trapped lung s/p pigtail cathter that is
   coninuously producing 400cc/day.  She is s/p a an open J tube placed.
   She had a prolonged ICU stay for afib RVR, hypotension and desats that
   improved with the pleuxex.
   While on the floor, she has been doing well. Open Gtube was placed by
   surgery on [**2191-5-16**], and she was started on TF on [**5-18**]. Her chest tube
   remained in place as there continued to be 300-400 cc clear drainage
   daily. The team was screening her for rehab. However, today, she went
   into afib with RVR with HR in 140's, developed a worsening oxygen
   requirement (from 2-3L NC to 70% HiFlow mask) to keep sats in mid to
   high 90's. She had reportedly received IVF boluses the previous night
   for low UOP. On the floor, she received lopressor 2.5 mg IV X 2 with
   improvement of HR to 100's. She recived 20 IV lasix with 800 cc UOP.
   She also received 2 mg IV morphine.
   Upon arrival to the ICU, she is not talking and appears uncomfortable.
   She cannot relate any further history.
   24Hr event:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and developed a large left pleural effusion. A pigtail catheter was inserted, but it continues to produce 400cc/day of fluid. The patient also has a tracheostomy tube (open J tube) in place. She had a prolonged ICU stay due to AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the placement of a pleural catheter. 

The patient experienced an episode of AF RVR while receiving IV fluids on the floor and required supplemental oxygen. Her current vital signs include a heart rate in the 100s, blood pressure of 94/61 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on HiFlow mask. 

Laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but elevated lactate levels. Blood, urine, and chest tube fluid cultures are negative. A transesophageal echocardiogram (TTE) reveals hyperdynamic left ventricular ejection fraction (70%), right ventricular dilation, mild mitral regurgitation, moderate pulmonary hypertension, and an atrial septal defect or patent foramen ovale.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia and subsequently developed a large left pleural effusion, which was managed with a pigtail catheter. The patient also has a trapped lung, open J-tube placement, and a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation. She returns today after receiving IV fluids on the floor and experiencing another episode of AF RVR with desaturation.

Assessment and Plan:

1. AFib with RVR: The patient continues to have episodes of AFib with RVR, which occurred during IV fluids administration. The plan is to continue amiodarone and diltiazem. If the heart rate cannot be controlled with diltiazem, a trial of verapamil will be given.

2. Fever and slight bandemia: The patient has a fever and a slight increase in white blood cell count. The plan is to pan culture and start Vanc/Zosyn for coverage. Treatment will be continued for 7 days and then stopped.

3. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is multifactorial, likely due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and right ventricular dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism (

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib RVR), hypoxia, and other medical conditions. She has been admitted to the ICU multiple times due to AFib RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with pleural catheter placement. The patient is currently experiencing fever, hypoexmia, and right ventricular (RV) failure. She has a history of large left pleural effusion and a trapped lung with a pigtail catheter in place. The patient is also on long-term antibiotics and anticoagulation therapy.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. AFib with RVR: The patient's episodes of AFib with RVR need to be managed with amiodarone and diltiazem. If the heart rate cannot be controlled with diltiazem, a trial of verapamil may be given.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxic respiratory failure is multifactorial and may be caused by HAP, left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and RV dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism (PE) hemodynamics. It is important to continue negative fluid balance and consider anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation.
3. Altered Mental Status: The patient's altered mental status may be related to sedating medications. Holding sedating medications and reassess

The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and developed a large left pleural effusion. A pigtail catheter was placed, and she continues to produce pleural fluid at a rate of 250cc per day. She has been in the ICU for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the pleural catheter. She returns to the ICU after receiving IV fluids on the floor, going into AF RVR and desaturating.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 105 bpm with atrial fibrillation, blood pressure ranging from 108/52 to 125/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93% on aerosol-cool. Fluid balance shows an input of 2,315 mL and output of 2,620 mL, resulting in a negative balance of 305 mL.

Renal function is impaired with creatinine levels consistently around 0.6 mg/dL. Other lab values show mild hypoglycemia, elevated liver enzymes, and electrolyte imbalances including hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypocalcemia.

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AFib with RVR), hypoxia, and a history of prolonged ICU stay. She returns to the ICU after receiving IV fluids on the floor, experiencing AFib with RVR and desaturation. The patient has a left pleural effusion and a trapped lung with a pigtail catheter in place since 5/10. She also has an open J-tube placed, and her pleural drainage is continuously producing 250cc. The patient's current issues include fever, hypoxemia, right ventricular failure, altered mental status, and borderline hypotension. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. AFib with RVR: The patient continues to have episodes of AFib with RVR, which occurred in the setting of IV fluids. She is currently on amiodarone and diltiazem for rate control. If the rate cannot be controlled with diltiazem, a trial of verapamil will be given.
2. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient's hypoxia is multifactorial and may be due to hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and right ventricular dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism (PE) hemodynamics. She will be treated empirically for PE, and anticoagulation will be initiated

   Assessment and Plan
   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called
   out from MICU after prolonged hospital course complicated by LLL
   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   # Mental status change:  Poor baseline wit underlying schizophrenia
   though MS [**First Name (Titles) 3548**] [**Last Name (Titles) 3549**] over [**Date range (1) 6300**].
   VBG yesterday showed increased hypercarbia, pt more arousable later in
   the day however. Increased WBC today concerning for possible infection.
   CXR done today without evidence of [**Date range (1) 3549**] pna. Her PICC and tubes
   looks okay. Aside from hypercarbia and infection, hyponatremia may also
   be contributory.
   - Repeat blood gas today, she may need BiPAP if retaining
   - Check urinalysis and urine culture, blood culture. Could check
   pleural fluid culture as well.
   # Metabolic alkalosis:  [**Month (only) 8**] be from diuresis with some underlying
   baseline hypercarbia and resulting metabolic alkalosis.
   Bicarbonate a little better today following acetazolamide.
   - Repeating blood gas as above
   - Hold on further diuresis today, BUN/Cr rising, Na dropping c/w
   intravascularly deplete state
   # Hyponatremia
   Suspect hypovolemic hyponatremia.
   - Hold off on further diuresis today and check PM electrolytes.
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. PE also remains on differential, and will treat emprically for
   PE. EKG without signs of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very
   high Pao2 suggestive of possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well,
   but Bubble study does show shunt, likely ASD/PFO.  Hypoxia appears
   improved.
   - Continue empiric LMWH for PE
   - Continue empiric vanc/zosyn for pna. Currently on day 6, plan to
   complete 8d course.
   - Chest tube clamped
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation:  She was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of
   the night, requiring additional BB doses. Not limited by hypotension.
   HR under better control with metoprolol.
   - Increase metoprolol to TID
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue lovenox/ASA
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Will not restart digoxin
   # HAP/[**Name (NI) 6220**] PNA Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly covered
   with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has completed
   course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions and a
   trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring bipap
   at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed evidence of
   numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**] did not
   reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR with increased effusion so pigtail
   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without
   worsening of effusion on CXRs since. Weaning O2 slowly.
   - if chest tube drainage less than 100 cc/day, can consider pulling the
   tube
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated
   - Xopenex/Ipratropium nebs
   - f/u IP recs
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - unclamp pigtail
   - f/u IP recommendations regarding pigtail, when to remove
   # ASD/PFO
   - continue to monitor
   # Aspiration: pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started
   # Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili

   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called
   out from MICU after prolonged hospital course complicated by LLL
   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   # Mental status change:  Poor baseline wit underlying schizophrenia
   though MS [**First Name (Titles) 3548**] [**Last Name (Titles) 3549**] over [**Date range (1) 6300**].
   VBG yesterday showed increased hypercarbia, pt more arousable later in
   the day however. Increased WBC today concerning for possible infection.
   - Repeat blood gas today, she may need BiPAP if retaining
   - Check urinalysis and urine culture, blood culture
   # Metabolic alkalosis:  [**Month (only) 8**] be from diuresis with some underlying
   baseline hypercarbia and resulting metabolic alkalosis.
   Bicarbonate a little better today following acetazolamide.
   - Repeating blood gas as above
   - Hold on further diuresis today, BUN/Cr rising, Na dropping c/w
   intravascularly deplete state
   # Fever: No fevers in the last day, but her WBC climbed up again today.
   CXR does not show evidence of worsening pna today and O2 requirement
   not [**Month (only) 3549**]. Recently ruled out for C diff.
   Recent fever as well as leukocytosis and bandemia. She has several
   possible sources including recurrent pna, UTI, pleural fluid. The
   persistant hypoxia depsite fluid removal as well as thick secretions is
   concerning for recurrent PNA, although this mornings CXR (obtained at
   time of spike) does not look much worse. The G tube site looks good and
   not infected. Now 48 hrs afebrile and with resolving leukocytosis.
   - f/u blood cx, urine cx, sputum cx, pleural fluid cx, stool cx
   - Continue Vanc/ Zosyn (Day 1: [**5-20**]; plan for 7 days) for broad coverage
   of HAP
   - Consider exchanging PICC if no improvement
   - Recheck C.diff to r/o x3
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. PE also remains on differential, and will treat emprically for
   PE. EKG without signs of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very
   high Pao2 suggestive of possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well,
   but Bubble study does show shunt, likely ASD/PFO. Started on heparin
   gtt and lasix gtt last night given TTE findings.
   - Lasix boluses to diurese 1L neg today
   - Continue lovenox empiric therapy of  PEs as needs anticoagulation for
   Afib as well
   - f/u infectious w/u
   - Continue intermittent clamping of chest tube to monitor
   reaccumulation of pleural effusion
   - d/w PCP
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation:  She was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of
   the night, requiring additional BB doses. Not limited by hypotension.
   - Continue diltiazem, titrate up carefully; consider changing to
   verapimil as a better nodal [**Doctor Last Name **]
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue lovenox/ASA
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Will not restart digoxin
   # HAP/Aspiraton PNA #1 - Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly
   covered with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has
   completed course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions
   and a trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring
   bipap at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed
   evidence of numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**]
   did not reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR with increased effusion so pigtail
   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without
   worsening of effusion on CXRs since. Weaning O2 slowly.
   - if chest tube drainage less than 100 cc/day, can consider pulling the
   tube
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated
   - Xopenex/Ipratropium nebs
   - f/u IP recs
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - unclamp pigtail
   - f/u IP recommendations regarding pigtail, when to remove
   # ASD/PFO
   - continue to monitor
   # Aspiration: pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started
   # Borderline hypotension- Her blood pressures have been running in the
   80's-90's systolic during her admission, asymptomatic. Here, blood
   pressure has been 100s recently, but now dipped to SBP 80
s after lasix
   and metoprolol. However, low BP, fever and bandemia could be impending
   sepsis. Given TTE findings, started on Lasix gtt yesterday to carefully
   diurese.
   - cont Lasix boluses for careful diuresis
   - no further interventions if asymptomatic , keep >50 if mentating at
   baseline
   # Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili
   also not elevated. Iron studies not c/w iron deficiency
   - continue to monitor

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. She was admitted to the ICU due to left lower lobe pneumonia, trap lung, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's current conditions include chronic pleural effusion, fever of unknown origin, hypoxemia, and atrial fibrillation.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Pleural Effusion, Chronic: The patient has a left-sided transudative pleural effusion with a trapped lung. She underwent thoracentesis and drainage of transudative fluid, which improved her respiratory status. A pigtail catheter was placed, resulting in the drainage of 1L of fluid. The chest tube drainage is less than 100 cc/day, and the decision will be made to pull the tube if this continues.
2. Fever, Unknown Origin: The patient's fever has resolved, but her white blood cell count is still elevated, indicating a possible infection. Further cultures will be obtained to rule out recurrent pneumonia, urinary tract infection, or other potential sources.
3. Hypoxemia: The patient's oxygen requirement has not improved despite fluid removal and clearing of secretions. A bubble study confirmed the presence of a shunt, likely an atrial septal defect (ASD) or patent foramen ovale (PFO). She was started on heparin gtt and Lasix g

Summary:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and hypertension. She was admitted to the ICU after a prolonged hospital course complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, tracheal malposition (trap lung), and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. 

The patient's current condition includes mental status change, metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, hypoxia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and ASD/PFO (atrial septal defect/patent foramen ovale). 

Key findings and plans include:
- Mental status change: The patient has poor baseline wit due to underlying schizophrenia, but there is a possibility of infection or other causes contributing to her mental status changes.
- Metabolic alkalosis: This is likely due to diuresis with some underlying baseline hypercarbia and resulting metabolic alkalosis.
- Hyponatremia: Suspect hypovolemic hyponatremia, which may be related to intravascularly depleted state. Hold off on further diuresis today and check PM electrolytes.

   86F with PMH schizoprenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, HTN called
   out from MICU after prolonged hospital course complicated by LLL
   pneumonia, trap lung, AF with RVR.
   # Mental status change:  Poor baseline wit underlying schizophrenia
   though MS [**First Name (Titles) 3548**] [**Last Name (Titles) 3549**] over [**Date range (1) 6300**].
   VBG yesterday showed increased hypercarbia, pt more arousable later in
   the day however. Increased WBC today concerning for possible infection.
   CXR done today without evidence of [**Date range (1) 3549**] pna. Her PICC and tubes
   looks okay.
   - Repeat blood gas today, she may need BiPAP if retaining
   - Check urinalysis and urine culture, blood culture. Could check
   pleural fluid culture as well.
   # Metabolic alkalosis:  [**Month (only) 8**] be from diuresis with some underlying
   baseline hypercarbia and resulting metabolic alkalosis.
   Bicarbonate a little better today following acetazolamide.
   - Repeating blood gas as above
   - Hold on further diuresis today, BUN/Cr rising, Na dropping c/w
   intravascularly deplete state
   # Hyponatremia
   Suspect hypovolemic hyponatremia.
   - Hold off on further diuresis today and check PM electrolytes.
   # Hypoxia: She has been hypoxic for numerous reasons this extended hosp
   course. PE also remains on differential, and will treat emprically for
   PE. EKG without signs of right heart strain. Of note, VBG shows very
   high Pao2 suggestive of possible shunt. Repeat ABG/VBG correlate well,
   but Bubble study does show shunt, likely ASD/PFO.  Hypoxia appears
   improved.
   - Continue empiric LMWH for PE
   - Continue empiric vanc/zosyn for pna. Currently on day 6, plan to
   complete 8d course.
   - Chest tube clamped
   # Paroxysmal Atrial fibrillation:  She was in RVR on admission with
   rate in the 150's responded to IV metoprolol x2. In and out of Afib on
   floor. She has been continued on low dose metoprolol since her
   admission for rate control, currently on PO lpressor. Lopressor
   frequency decreased yesterday but she became tachycardic for most of
   the night, requiring additional BB doses. Not limited by hypotension.
   HR under better control with metoprolol.
   - Increase metoprolol to TID
   - Continue Amiodarone
   - Continue lovenox/ASA
   - Monitor on telemetry
   - Will not restart digoxin
   # HAP/[**Name (NI) 6220**] PNA Pt initially admitted with LLL PNA broadly covered
   with antibiotics then narrowed to cefepime for which she has completed
   course. She subsequently developed large pleural effusions and a
   trapped lung on the left. Resp status deteriorated to requiring bipap
   at night and high flow mask constantly. Chest CT revealed evidence of
   numerous distal mucous plugs. However, Bronchoscopy on [**5-7**] did not
   reveal large mucous plugs. She then underwent thoracentesis and
   drainage of transudative fluid X 1, however, it quickly reaccumulated
   and she received an IP placed pigtail catheter with immediate drainage
   of large clear transudative fluid and improvement of her resp status
   back down to nasal cannula. She developed a small pneumothorax which
   was not symptomatic. Repeat CXR with increased effusion so pigtail
   unclamped and has drained 1 L.  Pigtail re-clamped yesterday, without
   worsening of effusion on CXRs since. Weaning O2 slowly.
   - if chest tube drainage less than 100 cc/day, can consider pulling the
   tube
   - cont chest PT, suctioning
   - wean 02 as tolerated
   - Xopenex/Ipratropium nebs
   - f/u IP recs
   # Pleural effusion: Pt has left sided transudative pleural effusion and
   trap lung with pigtail (placed [**5-10**]) in place. Had decreased BS on exam
   and slight increase in SOB so repeat CXR obtained which showed
   increased left sided effusion since pigtail clamped. Pigtail unclamped
   and has drained >100cc per day.
   - unclamp pigtail
   - f/u IP recommendations regarding pigtail, when to remove
   # ASD/PFO
   - continue to monitor
   # Aspiration: pt failed video swallow and is currently NPO. In the ICU
   question was raised whether aspiration is [**2-14**] stroke but no new focal
   neurological signs. G tube placed and TFs started
   - NPO
   - TFs started
   # Schizophrenia: Stable.
   - Continue depakote and perphenazine
   # Anemia- Currently stable, recent baseline HCT 25-28. LDH and bili
   also not elevated. Iron studies not c/w iron deficiency
   - continue to monitor

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, hypertension, and chronic left lower lobe pneumonia. She was admitted to the MICU after being called out from the floor due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient has had a prolonged hospital course complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, trap lung, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.

The patient's current conditions include pleural effusion, chronic; fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia); high risk for fall; hypoxemia; atrial fibrillation (AFIB). She also has a history of mental status change, metabolic alkalosis, hyponatremia, and hypoxia.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Pleural effusion, chronic: Continue empiric LMWH for PE; continue empiric vanc/zosyn for PNA. Currently on day 6, plan to complete 8-day course.
2. Fever, unknown origin (FUO, hyperthermia, pyrexia): Repeat blood gas today; she may need BiPAP if retaining; check urinalysis and urine culture, blood culture. Could check pleural fluid culture as well.
3. High risk for fall: Monitor closely for any falls.
4. Hypoxemia: Continue empiric LMWH for PE; continue empiric vanc/zosyn for P

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation (afib) with rapid ventricular response (RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA) and subsequently developed a large left pleural effusion. A pigtail catheter was placed, which is continuously draining fluid (currently at 170 cc/day). She also has a percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube, known as an open J tube, placed.

The patient has had a prolonged stay in the ICU due to afib with RVR, hypotension, and desaturation. She is currently experiencing episodes of afib with RVR, particularly after receiving IV fluids on the floor. Her vital signs include a temperature of 36.8°C, heart rate of 101 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 113/45 to 135/59 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96% on 40% FiO2. She is on aerosol-cool oxygen delivery and her arterial blood gas (ABG) shows a pH of 7.39, PaCO2 of 64 mmHg, and PaO2 of 129 mmHg.

Physical examination findings include alertness with confusion, inability to appreciate jugular venous pressure (JVP), irregular heartbeat

She has been admitted multiple times to the ICU for various issues including AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with pleural catheter placement. 

The patient's current presentation includes ongoing episodes of AF RVR, fever, hypoxemia, and right ventricular failure. She has a left-sided transudative pleural effusion and trapped lung with a pigtail catheter in place since May 10th. The patient also has a long-term indwelling J-tube for nutritional support. 

The patient's laboratory results show leukocytosis with a white blood cell count of 14.8 K/uL, elevated lactic acid levels, and mildly decreased albumin levels. Her electrolytes are within normal limits, but her renal function is impaired with elevated creatinine levels.

1. Cardiac Complications: The patient's history of AF RVR and right ventricular failure indicates ongoing cardiac dysfunction. The ongoing episodes of AF RVR need to be controlled to prevent further hemodynamic instability and hypoxemia.

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old female with a history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and other comorbidities. She was admitted to the ICU due to pneumonia, trap lung, atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, and mental status changes. The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.1°C, heart rate of 117 bpm, blood pressure of 135/89 mmHg, respiratory rate of 26 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. She is on mechanical ventilation with a nasal cannula.

The patient has been diagnosed with several medical complications, including hyponatremia, metabolic alkalosis, hypoxia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, ASD/PFO (atrial septal defect/patent foramen ovale), aspiration, schizophrenia, anemia, and possible urinary tract infection (UTI).

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, and platelet count within normal range. The blood cultures are pending, and the patient has positive urine culture for yeast.

Potential medical complications that can arise based on the provided information include worsening of pneumonia, further mental status deterioration, progression of atrial fibrillation, development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to prolonged immobilization, and worsening of hyponatremia.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 86-year-old female with a medical history of schizophrenia, paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, and a current admission complicated by left lower lobe pneumonia, aspiration risk, and atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. The patient's mental status has been fluctuating, and she has shown signs of increased hypercarbia, infection (positive urine analysis), and hyponatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Mental status change: The patient's baseline mental status is poor, underlying schizophrenia, and recent changes may be attributed to hypercarbia, infection, or hyponatremia.
2. Infection: Positive urine analysis suggests a possible urinary tract infection. Blood cultures are pending.
3. Hyponatremia: Suspected hypovolemic hyponatremia with slightly low sodium levels. Further evaluation and treatment are needed.
4. Metabolic alkalosis: The patient has metabolic alkalosis, which may be due to diuresis, baseline hypercarbia, and resulting metabolic alkalosis. Bicarbonate levels have improved.
5. Hypoxia: The patient has been hypoxic due to various reasons. A bubble study shows shunt, likely ASD/PFO. Oxygenation appears improved.
6. Paroxysmal atrial fibrillation: The patient has been in and out of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. Verapamil was started to control the heart rate.
7.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia (LLL PNA), subsequent large left effusion, and a trapped lung. A pigtail catheter was placed, but the patient continues to produce over 200 cc of fluid per day. She also has an open J-tube placed.

The patient has had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the pleural catheter. She returns to the ICU after receiving IV fluids on the floor, going into AF RVR, and desaturating.

The patient's current issues include continued pleural drainage, fever, hypoexmia (low oxygen levels), and right ventricular (RV) failure. She has positive findings for Foley catheter, increased free water, and an ethics consult called.

The patient's allergies include sulfonamides, olanzapine, risperidone, propranolol, and haloperidol. Her last dose of antibiotics was vancomycin and piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn) on 05/25/2191 at 09:00 AM and 11:39 PM, respectively.

The patient's medications include amiodarone, famotidine, enoxaparin,

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. She was admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia and developed a large left effusion, resulting in a trapped lung. A pigtail catheter was placed, and she has been producing approximately 170 cc of fluid per day. She also has an open J-tube placed. The patient had a prolonged ICU stay due to atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with pleural catheter placement. She returns after receiving IV fluids on the floor and experienced episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response and desaturation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient is experiencing hypoxic respiratory failure, which is multifactorial. It could be caused by hospital-acquired pneumonia, left pleural effusion, intracardiac shunt, and right ventricular dysfunction potentially representing pulmonary embolism hemodynamics.
2. Fever and Slight Bandemia: The patient has a fever and a slight increase in white blood cell count, indicating a possible infection. She has been pan-cultured and started on Vancomycin and Zosyn for coverage, which will be treated for 7 days.
3. Atrial Fibrillation with Rapid Ventricular Response: The patient continues to have episodes of atrial fibrillation with rapid vent

Summary:
The patient is an 86-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia, recurrent aspiration, and poorly controlled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response (AF RVR). She was initially admitted with left lower lobe pneumonia and subsequently developed a large left pleural effusion. A pigtail catheter was placed, and she continues to produce over 200 cc of fluid per day. She has had an open J-tube placed. She has had a prolonged ICU stay for AF RVR, hypotension, and desaturation, which improved with the pleural catheter. She returns after receiving IV fluids on the floor, going into AF RVR and desaturating.

Medical Complications:
1. AF RVR: The patient continues to have episodes of AF RVR, which occurred in the setting of IV fluids. Amiodarone and verapamil will be continued, and the dose of verapamil will be titrated up.
2. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, and free water will be stopped. A normal saline bolus will be given.
3. Fever and slight bandemia improved, so pan culture was done, and Vanc/Zosyn were started on 5/19 for coverage. The antibiotic regimen will be continued for 8 days and then stopped.
4. Hypoxic Respiratory Failure: The patient has multifactorial hypoxic respiratory failure likely due to HAP, left pleural
